answers.author: Maxwell Moline
answers.text:
Hello Edwin,
The City of Shoreline has a policy to limit critical comments about staff performance to private communication.
http://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/3884 
In Tulsa, all incoming and outgoing correspondences are stored digitally and searchable online. http://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/2837
Finally, the City of Carrolton has all correspondence featuring citizen complaints or concerns forwarded to the City Manager. http://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/12087
I hope this helps to answer your question. Please let us know if you need any more help.
Max Moline
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA

author: Edwin Pattison
text:
What is the typical policy on notifying the public / citizens of incoming city correspondence. This issue has become so controversial that the City Council has now requested a future agenda item to develop policy for notifying citizens of incoming city correspondence.
The reality is that a vocal small minority of citizens desires to use the city council package as a platform to "publish" attacks on the city and regularly submit much of the same false negative information. The current policy on incoming city correspondence is to list the "date, from/to, and subject in the council agenda under "correspondence."  If anyone desires a copy of the correspondence they can request a copy during business hours at the front desk.  The vocal minority are angered by this policy and want the entire text of their letters to the City published in the agenda package.  I am hoping other cities' may have dealt with this issue and have existing policy we can use as a comparison.
title: Incoming City Correspondence
